Please find the name of the catalyst and co-catalyst name from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
Please only generate the name of the catalyst and nothing else. Such as TiO2. ZrO2 or Ag, etc.
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
If there are multiple results, please indicate them as XXX-XXX.
catalyst: XXX
co_catalyst: XXX

evidence.pdf_reference: Tecnai G 2 F20 S-TWIN).The oxidation states were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Escalab 250XI).The optical properties of the obtained samples were obtained on a UVeVis spectrometer (Cary 5000). The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction test in H 2 O vapor was measured in a reactor with a top quartz window under A 300 W Xenon arc lamp (PLS-HXF 300, Beijing China Education Au-light Co. Ltd.) with a UV cutoff filter (l 400 nm).The about 85 mg catalyst was placed on a 2.0 A 2.0 cm 2 glass sheet
a new clue for designing Cu 2 Obased heterojunction photocatalysts for CO 2 reduction.

irradiation or photocatalyst and the photocatalytic activity was never discovered using the pure WO 3 and Cu 2 O photocatalysts.WO 3 and Cu 2 O exhibited no or negligible activities for CO 2 reduction, which were mainly attributed to the weak electron reduction ability of WO 3 and rapid recombination of photo-generated electron-hole pairs in Cu 2 O, respectively.As shown in Fig. 5, the WO 3 Cu 2 O composite samples all achieved the conversion from CO 2 to value-added products and variety kinds of products

and variety kinds of products was found and included the H 2 , O 2 , CO and CH 4 molecules, which was the reason that water-splitting reaction competed with the CO 2 reduction.According to 13 C labelled isotropic experiment (Fig. S3), the CO and CH 4 products were generated from CO 2 gas reactant in this study.With the Cu 2 O content of composites increasing, the yields of CO and CH 4 products were gradually promoted and the H 2 yield decreased and the percentage of CH 4 yield in catalytic productions also

CH 4 , H 2 and O 2 yields for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction still reached 4.76, 7.07, 0.40 and 11.84 mmol, respectively.It was revealed that the catalyst could maintain considerable activity.The XRD patterns and XPS spectra, which showed no apparent deterioration as compared to the fresh catalyst, supplied a powerful support for its stability (Figs.S6 andS7). Photocatalytic mechanism of the WO 3 Cu 2 O samples for CO 2 reduction was studied, according to the experimental results.In this study, the Cu 2 O

The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.

Lamp: ['Fluorescent', 'Mercury', 'Halogen', 'Mercury-Xenon', 'LED', 'Tungsten', 'Xenon', 'Tungsten-Halide', 'Solar Simulator']

evidence.pdf_reference: Tecnai G 2 F20 S-TWIN).The oxidation states were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Escalab 250XI).The optical properties of the obtained samples were obtained on a UVeVis spectrometer (Cary 5000). The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction test in H 2 O vapor was measured in a reactor with a top quartz window under A 300 W Xenon arc lamp (PLS-HXF 300, Beijing China Education Au-light Co. Ltd.) with a UV cutoff filter (l 400 nm).The about 85 mg catalyst was placed on a 2.0 A 2.0 cm 2 glass sheet

on a 2.0 A 2.0 cm 2 glass sheet inside the stainless steel cylindrical vessel reactor.Firstly, the reaction setup should be washed by the high purity CO 2 gas (99.999) for more 5 times.The mixture compressed gas, as reactant gas, was generated by the high purity CO 2 through a water bubbler.The gaseous products were got after visible-light illumination, which was then quantifiably identified using an off-line GC-7890II gas chromatograph with both a FID and a TCD using TDX-01 and Porapak-Q columns.In

TDX-01 and Porapak-Q columns.In cycling, the used sample was refreshed by water washing and vacuum drying, and then photocatalytic activity was reassessed.The isotopelabelled experiments were performed using 13 CO 2 instead of 12 CO 2 , and the products were analyzed using GC-MS (7890 A and 5975C, Agilent).I-t curves of the obtained samples were conducted using a CHI 660 E electrochemical workstation in a three-electrode system at test voltage of 0 V(vs.AgAgCl) 21.The morphology and structure of the

shown in Fig. 7, all product yields exhibited the escalation, prolonging the illumination time.Only small quantity of H 2 , as reduced production of water splitting, could be discovered after 12 h irradiation, which implied that the WO 3 Cu 2 O sample has the property of the selected catalysis.The yields of CO, CH 4 , H 2 and O 2 products could attain 7.04, 8.42, 0.80 and 16.27 mmol after 24 h visible-light illumination.As shown in Fig. S5, the experimental yield of O 2 was lower than the theoretical

and the maximal CO and CH 4 yields could attain 7.04 and 8.42 mmol after 24 h of visible-light irradiation.The photostability and photoactivity of Cu 2 O for CO 2 reduction were enhanced by the building of the WO 3 Cu 2 O heterojuntion.The Type II band alignment for WO 3 Cu 2 O heterojuntion was characterized by UV eVis reflectance and value-band X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy and the Z-scheme mechanism of photoinduced electron-hole was further proposed.This study could offer a new clue for designing Cu
